chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Eric Wayne Moses was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
In the event that the defendant is discharged from probation with outstanding financial obligations, the supervising agent SHALL notify the court 10 days prior to the revocation or discharge.  A civil judgment SHALL be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Consecutive to: Trempealeau County Case No. 21CF225
Concurrent with: Trempealeau County Case No. 22CF120

miscConds.notes: Defendant is to pay court costs.
Defendant to complete AODA Assessment and all follow through.
Defendant is to participate in the La Crosse County Recovery/Drug Court if accepted. If successfully completes, may petition for early discharge of probation.
Defendant is to work towards obtaining a GED.

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample. 

Defendant is to comply with any treatment/programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and agent.
Defendant not to possess or consume a controlled substance without a valid prescription.
